Features: The DIVA-HisDB dataset is used for text line segmentation in historical document image processing, particularly focusing on challenging medieval manuscripts. It provides precisely annotated high-resolution images with diverse layouts, including polygonal and sub-word bounding box annotations. The dataset is utilized for training, testing, and evaluating text line segmentation algorithms, emphasizing precision, recall, and the complexity of historical document layouts. It serves as ground truth for layout analysis and method effectiveness assessments in medieval manuscripts.

The Balsac dataset is used to evaluate and improve text line segmentation in historical documents, focusing on pixel-level performance and the impact of normalized ground-truth data on IoU scores. It is also used to annotate images with polygons, including line ascenders and descenders, and to assess the quality of these annotations for historical text recognition (HTR) systems. The dataset helps evaluate the spacing of text line polygons and trains handwritten document recognition systems, particularly for population records.

The ICDAR 2009: Handwriting Segmentation Contest dataset is used to evaluate the accuracy and robustness of text line segmentation algorithms in historical document processing. Researchers focus on segmenting handwritten lines, assessing algorithm performance through precision and reliability metrics. This dataset enables the development and refinement of techniques for handling the complexities of historical handwriting, enhancing the automated processing of archival materials.

The READ dataset is primarily used for automated text recognition in historical documents, particularly in the context of the ICFHR2018 competition. It focuses on developing and evaluating robust text recognition algorithms, including text line segmentation. This dataset enables researchers to test and improve the accuracy of automated text recognition systems, addressing challenges specific to historical documents.

The cBAD dataset is used for evaluating and assessing baseline detection algorithms and models in historical document images, focusing on text line segmentation. It contains 3021 annotated images from seven European archives and is utilized to test the accuracy and performance of methods such as U-Nets and RU-Net, enabling researchers to compare and refine their approaches in this specific domain.

The IAM-HistDB dataset is used to evaluate text line segmentation methods in historical documents, specifically covering a range of documents such as the Saint Gall, Parzival, and Washington databases, as well as Latin manuscripts with varying difficulties. This dataset enables researchers to assess the performance and robustness of segmentation algorithms across diverse historical texts.

The Saint Gall Database, as part of IAM-HistDB, is used to assess text line segmentation techniques in medieval manuscripts, particularly focusing on script and layout variations. It evaluates the accuracy of these techniques in medieval Latin manuscripts, enabling researchers to refine and compare different segmentation methods.

The WAHAD Database is utilized to test text line segmentation algorithms on a diverse set of handwritten historical documents. It highlights the algorithm's ability to handle variability in writing styles and assesses robustness in segmenting challenging, difficult-to-read texts. This dataset enables researchers to evaluate and improve the performance of segmentation techniques in historical document analysis.

The ICDAR 2019 HDRC-Chinese dataset is used to evaluate text line segmentation algorithms on Chinese historical documents, particularly focusing on complex layouts and handwriting styles. It assesses the performance of algorithms in handling intricate scripts and layouts, enabling researchers to improve the accuracy of text line segmentation in challenging historical documents.

The ICDAR 2013 Handwriting Segmentation Contest dataset is used to evaluate algorithms for text line segmentation, particularly in historical documents with diverse handwriting styles. It enables researchers to assess the effectiveness and robustness of their methods in handling varied and complex historical handwriting, ensuring accurate segmentation performance.

The H-DIVaR dataset is utilized for baseline detection in historical document images, particularly for the ICDAR2017 competition. It focuses on accurate baseline extraction, enabling researchers to improve the precision of text line segmentation in historical documents. This dataset supports methodologies aimed at enhancing the recognition and processing of historical texts by providing a benchmark for evaluating baseline detection algorithms.

The George Washington dataset is used to evaluate and validate text line segmentation algorithms on historical documents from the George Washington era. Research focuses on assessing the legibility and historical context of early American documents, emphasizing the accuracy and performance of segmentation techniques. This dataset enables researchers to test and refine algorithms specifically tailored for historical texts, ensuring they can effectively handle the unique characteristics of these documents.

The ANT4 dataset is used for evaluating the accuracy and robustness of text line segmentation algorithms on historical document images. Researchers employ this dataset to test and compare different segmentation methods, focusing on their performance in handling the complexities of historical documents. This enables advancements in the field of historical document analysis and preservation.

The VML-HD dataset is used for developing recognition systems in historical Arabic documents, specifically focusing on explicit pixel labeling for text line segmentation. This methodology involves precise identification and separation of text lines, enabling more accurate and reliable processing of historical documents. The dataset's detailed pixel-level annotations facilitate robust training and evaluation of segmentation algorithms, enhancing the overall performance of text recognition systems in this domain.

The HimanisAct dataset is used to train handwritten document recognition systems and to conduct text content-based layout analysis, particularly focusing on act-level annotations in historical documents. Comprising 739 pages from medieval manuscript collections, the dataset enables researchers to improve the accuracy of text recognition and analyze the structural layout of historical texts.

The cBAD2019 dataset is used for evaluating text line segmentation algorithms on historical documents, particularly focusing on complex layouts and degraded images. It assesses the robustness of these methods across various writing styles and conditions, serving as a benchmark in the ICDAR competition. This dataset enables researchers to test and compare the performance of different algorithms in challenging historical document scenarios.

The HOME-NACR dataset is used to evaluate text line segmentation performance on historical documents, especially those with ornate and varied layouts. The Horae dataset is used to evaluate text line segmentation methods on historical religious texts, particularly focusing on intricate layouts and high-resolution images. The READ-Complex dataset is employed to test text line segmentation algorithms on challenging historical documents, particularly those with complex layouts and low-quality images. The READ-Simple dataset is utilized for benchmarking text line segmentation models on simpler historical documents. The AHDB dataset is primarily used for testing and evaluating methods in Arabic handwritten text recognition and word extraction from Arabic handwritten documents. It achieves 86% accuracy in text recognition and focuses on F-measure for word extraction performance. The dataset is specifically designed to support research in these domains, enabling the development and assessment of algorithms tailored to Arabic script.

The 'text line segmentation dataset' is used to evaluate the accuracy and performance of text line extraction algorithms on 350 handwritten document images. The ICDAR 2013 test dataset is used to evaluate the performance of text line segmentation methods in historical documents. The IAM database is used to train and evaluate algorithms for text line segmentation in handwritten English texts, with a focus on accuracy and robustness. The Himanis-GMV dataset is used to study text line segmentation in historical documents, focusing on 1,435 pages from the dataset. The 'Church registers' dataset is used for line detection and segmentation in historical documents, particularly focusing on 18th and 19th-century church records. The BAMBI/Italian manuscripts dataset is used to segment cursive handwriting lines in 16th-century Italian gray-level manuscript images. The 'Church Registers images' dataset is used for line detection and segmentation in historical church registers, focusing on body baselines. Researchers employ image processing techniques to analyze these historical documents, enabling precise text line segmentation. The 'three medieval manuscripts' dataset is used for layout analysis in challenging medieval documents, particularly focusing on high complexity layouts. The UPTI dataset is used to analyze and segment ligatures in Urdu and Arabic document images, focusing on layout analysis and text line segmentation. The Maurdor dataset is used to evaluate box detection in scanned historical documents, specifically focusing on enhancing the accuracy of text line segmentation. The BALSAC Population Database is used to study historical document images, particularly 913 images of birth, marriage, and death records from 74 Québécois registers. The Parzival Database, as part of IAM-HistDB, is utilized to test text line segmentation algorithms on historical German texts. The Al-Majid dataset is used to evaluate seam carving techniques for text line extraction on color and grayscale historical manuscripts. The KHATT dataset is used to evaluate the performance of various architectures for handwritten text line segmentation, specifically focusing on the F-measure as the evaluation metric. Name (extracted): Southeast Asian palm leaf manuscript images

Name (extracted): database of unconstrained handwritten Polish documents

This dataset enables the assessment of different methodologies in handling the complexities of unconstrained handwriting, providing insights into improving text line segmentation techniques.

The NIST special database is used to test methods for text line segmentation in handwritten documents. The LOB corpus is used to conduct experiments on text line segmentation in historical documents, particularly focusing on handwriting recognition. Name (extracted): historical archives of the University of Athens
Features: The historical archives of the University of Athens are used to test the Block-Based Hough Transform approach for text line detection in unconstrained handwritten Greek documents. The dataset's relevance lies in its provision of authentic historical documents, enabling researchers to evaluate and refine text line segmentation techniques effectively.
